history.text: What did you think of the movie?
I really liked The Imitation Game, although I agree with Mr. Grant that no artistic license was needed as Mr. Turing's life is already so intriguing.
Do you have a favorite actor/ actress that was in the movie? I like Keira Knightly.
Benedict Cumberbatch is always a delight to watch.  Plus his name is quite fun.  Do you usually enjoy dramas?
I prefer something that is a little more comedic, but I also enjoy dramas.
I look forward to viewing more of Morten Tyldum's work.
Same here.
Do you like true to life stories?
Why yes I do!  The closer to the real story the better, although a thrilling adventure is never bad either.  Do you agree with the Rotten Tomatoes score?

I totally agree about it being closer to the real story. It is nice to add some artistic value to the story but not so much that it takes away from the story. I think the rotten tomatoes score is Okay. It may have been higher if it was closer to the real story. What do you think?
I think more truth would have lowered the score.  Unfortunately, people seem to want action more than truth.  But perhaps The Imitation Game found a good balance.
Did you see this at the movie theater?
I did not.  Did you realized the beginning of the movie took place in 1951?  How old would that have make Mr. Turing?
I would assume mid to late thirties, perhaps.
I did not realize that. Yes I would agree mid- to late thirties.
I wonder if, had Mr. Turing not been bullied, he and Mr. Morcom would still have become such close friends?
It is hard to imagine being sent away to boarding school, being away from your family and dealing with being bullied.
I completely agree.  I believe there is good in most situations.  The good out of this one is of course Enigma.
And to deal with our sexuality at a time when it was so taboo.
Indeed. How wonderful Mr. Turing must have felt having the support from his colleagues.  They would not hear of Mr. Turing's dismissal!
Mr. Turing and Miss Clarke seem to have found a mutually beneficial relationship in the end: he would not be lonely and she would be free of her parents.
I agree.
I can't imagine how difficult it must have been to choose with decoded attacks to allow and which to stop.
I wonder how it was that they were so strong to stand behind Turing.
Clarke must have been heartbroken to learn Turing never cared for her.

What a twist at the end... Mr. Cairncross being discovered as a spy, but Mr. Menzies knowing about it the whole time!  Mr. Turing risking it all to protect Miss Clarke... she must have know he was lying to her about not caring for her after that.

Perhaps, though, she never knew of his sacrifice
.
He had to have cared for her to risk what he did.
Sometimes we don't realize just how much someone cares for us.  And sometimes we never will.
I think many people hide behind a facade because they are afraid they will get hurt.
She must have cared for him in return since she did not turn him over to the police for his homosexuality.
All in all, great movie.
Agreed
